solution_line_template: A total of {initial_cars} + {new_customers} = <<{initial_cars}+{new_customers}={total_cars}>>{total_cars} cars are in the shop throughout the week.
This means the shop buys {total_cars} cars * {tires_per_car} tires = <<{total_cars}*{tires_per_car}={total_tires_bought}>>{total_tires_bought} tires.

For each of the customers that only want half the tires changing, there are {tires_per_car} tires * {half_fraction} = <<{tires_per_car}*{half_fraction}={tires_left_per_half_customer}>>{tires_left_per_half_customer} tires left over.

Two of the customers only want half the tires changing, so there are {tires_left_per_half_customer} tires * {num_half_customers} cars = <<{tires_left_per_half_customer}*{num_half_customers}={tires_left_from_half_customers}>>{tires_left_from_half_customers} tires left over from these customers.

Out of the remaining tires, there are {tires_left_end} - {tires_left_from_half_customers} = <<{tires_left_end}-{tires_left_from_half_customers}={tires_left_from_no_change}>>{tires_left_from_no_change} tires left from customers who don't want their tires changing.

So in total, there were {tires_left_from_no_change} tires / {tires_per_no_change_customer} tires per customer = <<{tires_left_from_no_change}/{tires_per_no_change_customer}={num_no_change_customers}>>{num_no_change_customers} customers who did not want their tires changing.
